question: Howdy.
answer: That the stage for Santa Inez?

question: Leaving any minute. Santa Inez -- seventeen-fifty -- Name?
answer: Rocklin. Mind if I ride alongside the driver?

question: It's all right with me -- if it's all right with Dave -- He's mad -- His last trip -- Had a row with Harolday, the boss -- Old-timer, Dave -- an' a grumpy old cuss.
answer: I like grumpy old cusses -- Hope to live long enough to be one.

question: Yeah? Here's your mail, Dave --
answer: -- and a passenger. Mind if I ride up here?

question: Where's them wimmen?
answer: Up at the hotel.

question: Why ain't they here? -- This is the stage depot, ain't it -- ? Ain't it?
answer: You can pick 'em up there -- it's only up the street --

question: On'y up the street -- an' they cain't walk it -- What's the matter -- don't Easterners have laigs like other folks?
answer: Hold tight when you git in the mountains, mister -- When he gits riled you can hear the passengers prayin' for miles.

question: Wait till I get you on the road, you old buzzard, you'll be surprised all right. I wonder why a young feller who don't have to wants to come into this God danged country? Say -- did you mean what you said back there about wimmen?
answer: Every word of it.

question: Then you're smarter than most.
answer: Maybe I seen more of 'em than most.

question: Shouldn't be surprised. Shouldn't be a leetle bit surprised. All the same...
answer: All the same -- what?

question: Take a slug. Whiskey and wimmen -- ever think how much alike they are? Both fool you, but you never figger out how to do without 'em. Take another.
answer: Not just yet.

question: Well... Here's to her.
answer: Who?

question: The next one that fools you. Mighty rough stretch along here.
answer: Like me to speel you a while?

question: Nope. I've had a few snorts but that don't make no difference. Leas'ways, never has... Don't ever git wore out, and useless, like me.
answer: Who're them as say you are?

question: Harolday, for one. Oh, I ain't belly- aching. Reckon he's entitled to his opinion. But him and me never did see eye to eye.
answer: What's wrong?

question: It's constitootional, I reckon. Like that step-daughter of his is crazy -- he's too sane. Believes In law and order.
answer: What's wrong with law and order?

question: Driver? Driver, what's the matter?
answer: Nothin'. Restin' hosses. Git out and stretch yore laigs if you want.

question: Resting horses? What for? I can see with my own eyes it's downhill.
answer: You in such an all-fired hurry, lady?

question: Certainly, we are in a hurry.
answer: Well -- we'll hurry some.

question: We stop here.
answer: Why do we stop here?

question: If you wanta eat and stretch yore laigs.
answer: Will you please stop referring to my legs!

question: Whar you been all these months?
answer: Up in the hills workin' my way down the biggest hole you ever seed.

question: Good -- What's at the bottom of it?
answer: Nothin'!

question: Yep -- this is my last trip.
answer: Why?

question: Old Harolday won't take back what he said.
answer: What'd he say?

question: Reckon so.
answer: Young man, that driver's had all the liquor he can take.

question: Has he?
answer: You know he has. You're not a complete fool, are you?

question: Frequently.
answer: The rudeness of people in these parts is appalling!

question: Where's Stan? We got to have another drink.
answer: He's outside tryin' to explain away a hide.

question: Eh?
answer: Seems we're eatin' stolen beef.

question: That's the way it is, Dave.
answer: Oh -- it's you.

question: That's right -- your old pal Bob Clews.
answer: Git away from me -- you two-timin' horse thief.

question: Them's fightin' words, pardner.
answer: Hey, Stan -- don't let 'em hang nothin' on you, you ain't done. They're just a couple of fourflushers -- the pair of 'em, everybody knows that.

question: What happened?
answer: Bumped his head.

question: Where -- on Iron Mountain?
answer: Where's the best chance of a cheap room?

question: There's Cap's place across the Street -- the Sun-Up Saloon.
answer: I'll pick that up later.

question: That's right; you didn't. Reason I ask is, a couple fellers was in saying how Dave was kickin' up a ruckus up at Stan's place. Sheriff Jackson it was and one of the Clewses.
answer: Oh!

question: Tough customers, the Clewses.
answer: Yeah -- don't pay to start something with 'em you don't intend to finish.

question: Pity they didn't string him up while they wore about it.
answer: That's what Arly Harolday was sayin' only this mornin'. You ain't met our Arly yet, I reckon?

question: He will, if he stays here long enough.
answer: Hell-fire in skirts.

question: One.
answer: One for me.

question: Don't you know that Queen is dead?
answer: I can take it if I want it.

question: Sure -- if you want -- but you'll have to beat my hand with four cards.
answer: I'm playing these, mister!

question: I don't like to tell men how to play cards unless I'm settin' in -- but I mebbe ought to have spoken up. That Queen was dead, Clint -- and you know it.
answer: When anybody plays poker with me, they play my game or not at all.

question: You can't just go makin' your own rules, Clint -- -- an' if I was you I'd hightail outa here before he comes back.
answer: Comes back?

question: I knocked, but guess you didn't hear me.
answer: What do you want?

question: Looks like you stirred things up around here last night, stranger.
answer: That all you came to say?

question: No. I got a message for you. From Old Man Harolday. Wants to see you out front.
answer: What about?

question: Maybe he wants to thank you for teaching that pup of his a lesson.
answer: I'll be down.

question: Is your name Rocklin?
answer: Yes.

question: I want that money you took from my brother last night.
answer: Are you crazy? Or just ignorant?

question: I don't understand. Job? What job?
answer: Foreman.

question: On the "K.C."? But -- but why should he want you?
answer: Why not? Good foremen don't grow on bushes.

question: Is that your only motive for coming here?
answer: What other motive could I have?

question: I don't know -- It's just that Red Caldwell was a peculiar man -- had a funny way of doing things. Well, I'm sorry, Mr. Rocklin, that you've been brought all this way on a fool's errand, but -- I'm afraid the deal's off.
answer: Off?

question: I don't want to be too hard on you, but as executor of the estate I have to consider the interests of the new owner. How about, say, a hundred in full settlement?
answer: Well --

question: That's my last word -- think it over. How do you do, ladies --
answer: You are Judge Garvey, I presume.

question: Yes -- and you are --
answer: Miss Martin -- and my niece, Clara Caldwell.

question: Of course -- of course -- You came at a very opportune moment, madam. This gentleman claims to have some sort of a letter from the late Mr. Caldwell, engaging him as foreman of the "K.C."
answer: What!

question: What!
answer: What do you mean -- claims to have? -- You saw it, didn't you?

question: You can't hold us to account for every promise made by that man. Everyone knows he wasn't responsible for his actions half the time. And if you think I'd have you as a foreman --
answer: Listen, lady -- I'd rather walk for somebody else, than ride for you.

question: Well -- the impudence --
answer: All I come for this morning was to pay beck the hundred and fifty Red Caldwell sent in advance.

question: The railway fare -- well, I reckon we can check that up against the time lost and call it quits.
answer: But, Mr. -- er -- I don't know your name...

question: Rocklin, miss.
answer: Mr. Rocklin, it isn't fair for you to pay anything back.

question: That's how I'd prefer it, If you don't mind, miss -- never did care fer owing favors to no one -- especially women.
answer: Oh!

question: I've just heard they let George Clews out of penitentiary and that he's headed this way. You might tell him from me, if he sets foot on the Santee Ranch, I'll shoot him on sight.
answer: But really, Miss Arly, why should you deliver your message through me?

question: You have mutual friends.
answer: If you're referring to Sheriff Jackson...

question: I am.
answer: But that's absurd. The fact that he employs one of the Clews brothers doesn't make the other his friend.

question: Have it your own way; but it'd be fair to warn him, because I mean it.
answer: Oh, Miss Caldwell, this is Miss Harolday -- Miss Martin, Miss Caldwell's aunt. You should know one another, seeing you'll be neighbors. Miss Harolday runs the Santee Ranch for her stepfather. She's a famous -- ah -- horsewoman in these parts.

question: I've a message for you -- from Harolday.
answer: What, again?

question: He wants you to come down to the office.
answer: What for?

question: He's got a proposition to make -- about riding for him. Sixty a month.
answer: Hmmm -- That's a foreman's wages.

question: The best friend I've got. Wait here. I've just hired a man named Rocklin and said you made me do it. Sixty dollars and he 'll earn it -- while he lasts.
answer: Why did you do it, Arly?

question: So I can fire him. I hate him. Clint and he quarrelled last night. Clint lied about it and I made a fool of myself. He's outside now.
answer: All right. Send him in.

question: Come in.
answer: Mr. Rocklin, what happened between you and my son last night?

question: Mr. Rocklin, what happened between you and my son last night?
answer: Poker.

question: Hmmm. About this suggestion of you working for me.
answer: It's your suggestion, not mine.

question: Ye-es. Sixty dollars is big money.
answer: If you've changed your mind...

question: No, no.... Wait a minute. I take it you've had the experience.
answer: Enough for Red Caldwell to hire me as foreman.

question: Oh -- had Caldwell hired you?
answer: Yeah -- but I won't ride for the new owners -- so that leaves me open.

question: I see -- Were you a friend of Red's?
answer: No -- I guess he just heard about me.

question: If he comes in again -- I'll throw you.
answer: That does it, boys -- you know where the door is.

question: Com-mon -- I'll get his ears.
answer: Not until I get my money -- There's three drinks and a broken beer glass.

question: -- Now what was that you were sayin' about Caldwell?
answer: You being hired by Red Caldwell only confirms what I'd suspected -- he was getting ready to fight.

question: Fight? Who?
answer: Organized rustling. Well at least -- that's my belief. Red was no friend of mine. Too fond of taking the law into his own hands. But he had my sympathy. He'd been harder hit than any of us. And on top of it all, he lost his foreman.

question: You mean, he quit on him?
answer: He was shot -- in the back -- with a bullet from the same caliber rifle as got Red.

question: Got any ideas?
answer: No -- Except that the man you just pistol-whipped is in on it somewhere. Pity you didn't kill him when you had the chance.

question: Say -- it don't sound as if it's goin' to be too easy for them wimmen at the K.C.
answer: Want to go back and work for them?

question: No, sir. And I ain't jumping at this offer o' yours either because I don't hold with working for wimmen.
answer: Oh, you mean my step-daughter. Well don't worry. She won't interfere with you...Rocklin -- I figure we've been losin' cattle over a place called Table Top -- it's the back way into the Topaz Ranch and the perfect route for rustlers -- I'm going to send you up to the line camp -- you don't mind working a lone hand -- do you?

question: -- I like workin' that way.
answer: Good -- be ready to move out this afternoon.

question: Whar you off to?
answer: I'm riding for the Topaz Ranch.

question: What! -- Have you gone plumb loco?
answer: Good money -- sixty a month

question: There ain't enough money in this town to make it worth your while to work for that gal. When she gits goin' she can be meaner'n a skillet full o' snakes. She ain't goin' to forget the way you made a fool of her today -- in front of the whole town. Be right with you. It's pizen that's what it is -- jus' plain --- What you want to hang around this town for anyways? --
answer: Be right with you.

question: The trail is straight ahead. You will find the cabin at the top. Adios, Senor.
answer: Senor Romerez, it appears that you do not like me.

question: Senor, that is true. I do not like you.
answer: Why?

question: Hiya there.
answer: Buenos dias, Senor Dave. You have found new employer, eh?

question: Yeah. Haulin' freight for ole Pap Fossler. Got a letter here for that crazy galoot, Rocklin. From the little Caldwell girl. Seems mighty took up about sumpin'. Made me promise to deliver it personal.
answer: But Senor Rocklin is not here.

question: Lordy -- he ain't quit already...
answer: I have just accompany him to Table- Top.

question: Have you seen Arly?
answer: As Arly moves toward the porch, Shelley snaps back to life and resumes sweeping -- but furiously. Clint regards the girl in the vague manner of the puzzled gent he is.

question: 'Mornin', Arly --
answer: 'Mornin', Clint.

question: You must be feeling pretty good. Say, Arly -- about that poker game, night before last, I ---
answer: Forget it.

question: Forget it?
answer: Tala. Well --

question: What is this? --
answer: What do you mean?

question: What do I mean? --
answer: Good morning, Tala.

question: Have my horse saddled and sent around right away -- will you? You can have that Rocklin bring it. What's the matter?
answer: Rocklin is not here.

question: He quit?
answer: He has gone to the line camp at Table Top.

question: What?
answer: It was Mr. Harolday's orders. Why do you make your heart heavy with thoughts of him, little one. -- He is not for you.

question: Be quiet.
answer: He has made the choice, Arliete. With your own eyes you saw it yesterday.

question: Oh --
answer: And she, too, has opened her heart to him -- Already she has summoned him to her.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Dave -- of the white beard -- carries a letter to Rocklin -- It is from her.

question: How do you know that?
answer: I have just now met Dave, and he tell me. -- So now he rides to Table Top. Little one you --

question: Good morning, Julio -- morning Arly. Fetch my briefcase -- it's on my desk. Looks like we're going to get that land we've been wanting along the river bottom. I didn't tell you -- but I bought the mortgage on the Hardman ranch, and it's due today -- On my way over there now.
answer: Did you send that Rocklin to Table- Top?

question: I did.
answer: Well, let's get things straight. This place was my mother's -- now it's mine and Clint's -- It's true you've been helping out -- but the way things are going we'll soon be able to pay you back every penny we owe. Meanwhile, I'm running this outfit and I expect to give the orders.

question: You generally do.
answer: Why did you send Rocklin up to Table- Top?

question: It seemed to me a good idea -- what with all this rustling going on --
answer: Who'd ever try driving cattle over Table-Top? -- Unless they were crazy.

question: I don't agree with you. In any case -- if you must have it -- I'd no intention of engaging a man at foreman's wages just to gratify the whims of a jealous woman!
answer: You take care what you're saying.

question: Durn funny -- that storm quittin' just about the time I get here.
answer: No funnier than you sloggin' through it, just to deliver a letter from a woman.

question: Reckon I'm gettin' to be more of a fool the older I get. When are we gonna get around to readin' it?
answer: Thought I'd wait till mornin' -- might be bad news an' I wouldn't be able to sleep.

question: Mmmm -- dineroo. Who wouldn't be -- livin' with that ole screech owl.
answer: I am desperately in need of help and advice from someone whom I feel I can trust, and I am appealing to you, because I regard you in the same way my Uncle surely must have. I heartily dislike and distrust Judge Garvey --

question: Huh -- Smart girl --
answer: But my Aunt seems to have suddenly revised her opinion of him, and now wants me to place all my affairs in the Judge's hands and return east. Such is certainly not my wish.

question: Looks kinda like she's formed an attachment. For the locality, I mean.
answer: I wanted so much to give ranch life a trial, but fear circumstances are against me, especially in view of the recent Indian trouble --

question: Indian trouble -- Good Lord, they ain't been any Indian trouble around here in --
answer: You want to hear the rest of this?

question: Might's well -- come this far.
answer: I want to apologize for what took place this afternoon. And I am returning the 150, because I feel it is rightfully yours. You must take it. Faithfully yours, Clara Caldwell.

question: Well -- what do you make of it?
answer: Somebody's sure bustin' to get her out of there.

question: Indian trouble --
answer: Wonder why the old lady's playin' along?

question: Baaa -- Wimmen -- Who can ever figure 'em? Got to admit though, I feel a mite sorry for the young'un -- nice little tyke.
answer: Too nice for this country.

question: She's shore a pretty thing.
answer: Don't know how I could help her -- even if I wanted to -- I don't know any thing about this Garvey -- or Caldwell -- or --

question: Well, now -- I could mebbe help you out some, there -- Fact, I could tell you somethin' 'bout ole Red that might be interestin'.
answer: You must have known him pretty well -- What kind of a man was he?

question: Caldwell? -- The best -- cantankerous cuss -- but a real cowman, believe me -- He was a big feller, like yourself -- Fact, you coulda passed fer a blood relation, come to think of it.
answer: Was the Judge and Red friends?

question: That's what you'd say. Garvey managed all Red's business. Besides which they was regular drinkin' pals -- played poker together most nights -- tho' they do say Red got the worst of it.
answer: Red was a gambler, eh?

question: Oh, yeah -- reckon a pretty poor one, tho' -- still you'd say him and Garvey was friends.
answer: Anything ever happen to make you think they weren't?

question: Rock -- I'm gonna tell you somethin' I ain't never told anybody.
answer: Think you can trust me?

question: The last time I seen Red was the day he died -- -- 'Twas in town -- he jus' come out of the stage office. Tried to book passage to Garden City but couldn't on account I had a full load. -- Well, sir, he took me aside and give me a printed sheet of paper and says, "Read it." I looked it over and fer as I could see it was a paper from one of them Chicago sportin' firms, tellin' how to manipulate trick playin' cards.
answer: Marked cards.

question: Reckon so. -- Seems Red found some cards and this paper in a coat one of his friends loaned him one night.
answer: Whose was it?

question: Well, now that's just what I asked -- but all he said, was that it belonged to a good friend. Then he said he wasn't waitin' fer the next coach, but was ridin' over to see the district judge about it alone.
answer: That's when they got him.

question: Yes, sir -- 'bout a mile or so from Stan's place. A bullet in the back an' his pockets empty.
answer: How come you never told this before?

question: Who was there to tell? -- Sheriff Jackson? -- Him an' Garvey's thick as thieves.
answer: How about what's his name -- Harolday? -- He's no friend of the Judge's, is he?

question: Hates his guts -- sure riles him to see young Clint hangin' onto the Judge's coattails. All the same, I jus' decided to keep my mouth shut and my eyes open.
answer: Even if it was Garvey Red was talkin' about -- it don't follow that he killed him.

question: No -- general opinion is that it was rustlers.
answer: Why would rustlers take the evidence Caldwell had with him?

question: Looks to me if you get the man who owned the marked cards, you get the killer.
answer: Funny tho' -- first the K.C. foreman -- then Caldwell -- an' now these women.

question: Lordy -- you ain't thinkin' somebody might try bumpin' them?
answer: I'm not so sure somebody hasn't tried already -- Remember, when we stopped to change horses on the way Over from Garden City --

question: Shore -- you told me how Jackson and Clews tried to frame Stan.
answer: Yeah. Like they wanted to be sure he'd keep his mouth shut about something.

question: And layin' that gun across my skull -- an' offerin' to drive the coach themselves.
answer: It was almost as if -- You all right?

question: Will be if I ever get dry.
answer: Lookit that --

question: Good Lord --
answer: Come on --

question: My team.
answer: That's not your team.

question: Come on --
answer: No use -- he's gone.

question: Mebbe we winged him.
answer: Not bad shootin'.

question: Not bad shootin'.
answer: You think I did that?

question: Sure -- to draw us away from here. You know, you cut it mighty close -- Good thing I ain't got brains enough to fill it. Too bad you had to come 'way up here through that storm for nothin'.
answer: I haven't minded a bit -- -- because I came up to fire you.

question: Oh -- I see.
answer: Get out of here -- get off the Santee and don't ever come back.

question: Mind if I wait for Dave? He ought to be along any minute -- Be funny if he winged that shadow of yours.
answer: If you mean Juan -- you're loco. He's not even up here.

question: You came up alone?
answer: Yes.

question: Then who was that we took out after?
answer: The man who shot at you.

question: Who was he?
answer: I don't know.

question: You mean you won't tell.
answer: I mean I don't know -- Why should I lie to you?

question: You work for Harolday? Here's one of his horses -- I'll pick up my saddle later. Howdy...
answer: I thought I sent you up to Table- Top.

question: That's right.
answer: What happened?

question: Well, this, for one thing.
answer: I told you you'd regret letting that rat Clews off so easy. What's the matter? Don't you think it was him, then?

question: I been figgerin'. Don't seem reasonable Clews was in condition to take that sort of chance alone... Besides -- how could he have known I was up there -- that soon. And -- George Clews ain't the only one I've run contrariwise to in this town. There's that Mexican, for instance.
answer: Juan?

question: Oh, Mr. Rocklin -- I'm so glad I've found you -- I was on my way to the Santee and learned you were in town.
answer: Just got in.

question: I feel perfectly awful, running after you like this, but --
answer: You got trouble, eh?

question: My aunt found out I wrote you and made a terrible scene --
answer: You haven't signed everything over to that Garvey, have you?

question: No -- and because I refused, Auntie said she would sign an affidavit that I'm still underage, and then, as my guardian she can do what she likes.
answer: Got anything to prove you're not underage?

question: No -- but Mr. Garvey has a letter that would prove it. My aunt wrote it before we came out here.
answer: S'pose we could get it?

question: He'd never give it to me.
answer: Wait here.

question: That takes care of that -- Now, I'll draw up an affidavit right away and everything will be taken care of as we want it.
answer: I certainly hope so -- it's not myself I'm concerned about --

question: -- Of course not.
answer: I can't say I'm very happy about doing this -- I only hope it works out for the best.

question: It's the better choice of two evils -- now let's see -- I, Elizabeth -- It is Elizabeth, isn't it?
answer: Yes --

question: -- Elizabeth Martin, of Danvers, Massachusetts, do hereby -- Well, Mr. Rocklin, this is indeed a surprise. Didn't expect to see you so soon. I understood you were riding for the Santee.
answer: That's right.

question: Perhaps you'd better come back later -- Did you say letter?
answer: That's right -- the one Miss Caldwell's aunt wrote from out east sayin' she was of age. Remember?

question: What is your interest in this letter?
answer: My only interest is getting' it.

question: You realize what this is, don't you? -- Robbing -- armed robbery at that. I warn you, you're in for a disappointment.
answer: Open up.

question: Listens, you -- There's nothing in there that'd interest you.
answer: I'd like to make up my own mind about that.

question: All right -- I'll open it -- just to convince you I'm not hiding any letter. What's the idea?
answer: These cards --

question: Anything wrong in a man having cards in his possession?
answer: Depends on what kind they are -- 'specially when they're under lock and key.

question: You're taking those, I presume.
answer: That's right.

question: Now, you look here --
answer: You're the one who better start lookin' -- lookin' for a way out for killin' Red Caldwell.

question: Caldwell --
answer: He found out about these -- and you went and killed him.

question: And you believe a story like that?
answer: I will until I hear a better one. I'll just take this along -- the district judge at Garden City should be mighty interested.

question: No trouble at all -- I'm going anyway.
answer: You look like you've been fighting.

question: What are you doin' here?
answer: I was just telling Miss Caldwell about -- well -- you and me.

question: Well -- why should I deny it?...
answer: And didn't you make love to me?

question: Make love to you --
answer: You didn't kiss me -- I suppose?

question: Did you expect me to deny that, too?
answer: You see?

question: She's lovely, isn't she? -- So sweet -- honest, and helpless. Pity you didn't fall in love with her, instead of me.
answer: You might's well know right now that you or no woman is ever goin' to get me.

question: Don't be so sure -- I don't think I'm doin' so badly.
answer: Don't you?

question: Don't you know?
answer: I know there ain't a dirty trick you wouldn't play to get what you want.

question: Clint -- I want you to tell me why Garvey murdered Red Caldwell -- You know -- don't you?
answer: Me? No!

question: Oh yes you do. And you're going to tell me all about it.
answer: I don't know nothing, I tell you --

question: Talk!
answer: I tell ya, I...

question: But you didn't fire it.
answer: That's right.

question: What happened?
answer: Clint and me was having a bit of an argument.

question: What about?
answer: About whether he was going to help clear up a few things that's been bothering me and some others 'round these parts. For instance -- who it was shot Red Caldwell.

question: You vile, ungrateful strumpet -- running away in the night, like a deceitful sneak-thief --
answer: Yes -- I'm running away -- and it's all your fault -- you're the one who's been deceitful and sneaking -- and don't think I don't know what you intend doing.

question: -- And don't think I don't know what you intend doing.
answer: I don't care -- I'm not ashamed of it -- and nothing you can say or do is going to stop me.

question: You little fool -- if you go to Garden City with that man -- you stand to lose everything.
answer: But why? -- Why are you being so secretive? -- If you know something, why don't you tell me?

question: You seem to like to do business through windows, Mr. Harolday. You're not Clint's killer, by any chance --
answer: By one bad chance -- Juan saw you do it.

question: Well, now we're gettin' some place --
answer: That pouch is his -- Juan made it for him a long time ago. Didn't you?

question: I guess there's no rush for you to get to Garden City, now --
answer: No -- I don't suppose there's any -- rush -- If I was like her, I'd stay in the West.

question: That means you're goin' back East -- Cousin Clara?
answer: It's where I belong -- I know that now --

question: It's good to know where you Belong, I reckon -- Wish I knew.
answer: I can tell you -- you belong with her --

question: Thanks.
answer: For what?

question: Everything.
answer: Beautiful day.

question: It didn't start out so beautiful.
answer: That's true of lots of things.

question: Fer instance?
answer: Well -- you and -- me.
